# `noDirectMutationState.test.ts`

**DO NOT MODIFY**. This file has been autogenerated. Run `rome test packages/@romefrontend/compiler/lint/rules/react/noDirectMutationState.test.ts --update-snapshots` to update.

## `Prevent direct mutation of this.state`

### `0`

```

 lint/react/noDirectMutationState/reject/1/file.tsx:4:14 lint/react/noDirectMutationState ━━━━━━━━━━

  ✖ Avoid mutating this.state directly.

    2 │           class Hello extends React.Component {
    3 │             testFunc() {
  > 4 │               this.state.foo++;
      │               ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
    5 │               return <div>Hello {this.props.name}</div>;
    6 │             }

  ℹ Calling setState() after mutating this.state directly may replace the mutation you made. The
    only place you may set this.state directly is in a constructor of a react class component.

━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━

✖ Found 1 problem

```

### `0: formatted`

```
class Hello extends React.Component {
	testFunc() {
		this.state.foo++;
		return <div>
			Hello 
			{this.props.name}
		</div>;
	}
}

```

 lint/react/noDirectMutationState/reject/3/file.tsx:4:14 lint/react/noDirectMutationState ━━━━━━━━━━

  ✖ Avoid mutating this.state directly.

    2 │           class Hello extends React.Component {
    3 │             testFunc() {
  > 4 │               this.state.foo += "bar";
      │               ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
    5 │               return <div>Hello {this.props.name}</div>;

```

 lint/react/noDirectMutationState/reject/4/file.tsx:4:14 lint/react/noDirectMutationState ━━━━━━━━━━

  ✖ Avoid mutating this.state directly.

    2 │           class Hello extends React.Component {
    3 │             testFunc() {
  > 4 │               delete this.state.foo;
      │               ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
    5 │               return <div>Hello {this.props.name}</div>;
    6 │             }

### `5: formatted`

```
class Hello extends React.Component {
	testFunc() {
		this.state.person.name.first = "bar";
		this.state.person.name.last = "baz";
		return <div>
			Hello
		</div>;
	}
}

```

		});

}

### `16`

```

 lint/react/noDirectMutationState/reject/17/file.tsx:4:16 lint/react/noDirectMutationState ━━━━━━━━━

  ✖ Avoid mutating this.state directly.

    2 │             class Hello extends React.PureComponent {
    3 │               componentWillUnmount() {
  > 4 │                 this.state.foo = "bar";
      │                 ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
    5 │               }
    6 │             }

  ℹ Calling setState() after mutating this.state directly may replace the mutation you made. The
    only place you may set this.state directly is in a constructor of a react class component.

━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━

✖ Found 1 problem

```

### `16: formatted`

```
class Hello extends React.PureComponent {
	componentWillUnmount() {
		this.state.foo = "bar";
	}
}

```

### `17`

```

 lint/react/noDirectMutationState/reject/18/file.tsx:4:16 lint/react/noDirectMutationState ━━━━━━━━━

  ✖ Avoid mutating this.state directly.

    2 │             class Hello extends PureComponent {
    3 │               componentWillUnmount() {
  > 4 │                 this.state.foo = "bar";
      │                 ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
    5 │               }
    6 │             }

  ℹ Calling setState() after mutating this.state directly may replace the mutation you made. The
    only place you may set this.state directly is in a constructor of a react class component.
